title: How to Make Marbled Crayons

steps.headline: Gather together all of your old crayons.
steps.description: you can use all types of colours but try to get a variety. Do this so the marbled crayons will become more interesting and colourful.

steps.headline: Remove all of the paper from the crayons.
steps.description: The paper shouldn't form part of the new crayons and removing it makes them easier to cut.

steps.headline: Use a sharp knife to cut the crayons into small pieces.
steps.description: Keep the pieces together in a container as you continue to cut.

steps.headline: Turn the oven to 140ºC/275ºF.
steps.description: Ensure that the oven is preheated before you put the crayons in.

steps.headline: Line a muffin pan with foil.
steps.description: Each hole must be fully covered, without any tears or holes in the foil. For neater shapes, try using silicone cupcake cups. They won't wrinkle like tin foil.

steps.headline: Place a few of crayon pieces into each hole of the muffin pan.
steps.description: You could make multicoloured marbled crayons, where you put one of each colour each in. On the other hand, you could stick to the same colour but add different shades of that same colour. For example, you could do a pink crayon but use rose, orchid, fuchsia, baby pink, coral, hot pink, etc.

steps.headline: Place the muffin pan with crayon pieces into the preheated oven.
steps.description: Leave the crayons for a few minutes or until they have fully melted. Then remove from the oven, using oven mitts to protect your hands.

steps.headline: If the melted wax has not created a marbled effect, use the end of a spoon to gently mix it together.
steps.description: Wash the end of the spoon immediately before it solidifies.

steps.headline: Leave the melted crayons for a few minutes to cool and set.
When they have fully cooled remove from the tray.
steps.description: You now have great, recycled, circular crayons.

text: Sourcing and Preparing Materials Gather together all of your old crayons. you can use all types of colours but try to get a variety. Do this so the marbled crayons will become more interesting and colourful. Remove all of the paper from the crayons. The paper shouldn't form part of the new crayons and removing it makes them easier to cut. Use a sharp knife to cut the crayons into small pieces. Keep the pieces together in a container as you continue to cut. Making the Marbled Crayons Turn the oven to 140ºC/275ºF. Ensure that the oven is preheated before you put the crayons in. Line a muffin pan with foil. Each hole must be fully covered, without any tears or holes in the foil. For neater shapes, try using silicone cupcake cups. They won't wrinkle like tin foil. Place a few of crayon pieces into each hole of the muffin pan. You could make multicoloured marbled crayons, where you put one of each colour each in. On the other hand, you could stick to the same colour but add different shades of that same colour. For example, you could do a pink crayon but use rose, orchid, fuchsia, baby pink, coral, hot pink, etc. Baking the Crayons Place the muffin pan with crayon pieces into the preheated oven. Leave the crayons for a few minutes or until they have fully melted. Then remove from the oven, using oven mitts to protect your hands. If the melted wax has not created a marbled effect, use the end of a spoon to gently mix it together. Wash the end of the spoon immediately before it solidifies. Leave the melted crayons for a few minutes to cool and set.  When they have fully cooled remove from the tray. You now have great, recycled, circular crayons. Finished.
